resources.string: RelativeLayout, an Android layout. To use it you must align its components relative to parent or other components (siblings)

LinearLayout, an Android layout. It works by sorting the components linearly, can be horizontal or vertical. By default, it always sorting its components from up to bottom (if vertical) or from left to right (if horizontal).

Currently the last and newer layout built by Android. It allows build big and complexes layouts. It looks like the RelativeLayout, the components are align to parent or siblings but is more flexible and easy to use with Android Studio\'s Layout Editor. You must add at least one horizontal and one vertical constraint for the component.

FrameLayout, an Android layout. It works with layers, you can display components over the others in the order they are defined in layout XML, like an image over other image and etc. You must use layout_gravity to position the views.
